info.name: roboHoover
info.description:
Author: Matt Deakin
Last update: 11/1/2021

This collection is an answer to the Platform Science code test:
https://bitbucket.org/platformscience/pltsci-sdet-assignment/src/main/

Requirements
Docker v.18+
Building the service
From the root of this repository, run the following:

sudo chmod +x service/run.sh
docker build -t pltsci-sdet-assignment service
Running the service
docker run -d -p 8080:8080 --name pltsci-sdet-assignment pltsci-sdet-assignment
Hitting the endpoint
You can test whether the service is running correctly by executing the following command: - curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -X POST -d '{ "roomSize" : [5, 5], "coords" : [1, 2], "patches" : [ [1, 0], [2, 2], [2, 3] ], "instructions" : "NNESEESWNWW" }' http://localhost:8080/v1/cleaning-sessions

item.description:
Requests in this folder test the movement of the Hoover.

We check five good examples based on start, directions and ending position.

There are also some tests based on bumping into walls.

item.name: Dirt

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description: Basic test of a straight path cleaning one dirt path.

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description: Verify that passing over two dirt patches results in a count of 2.

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description: This is the same as 'Dirt 2' with the order of dirt patches specified reversed.

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description: Hoover passes over the same dirt patch three times.  This should verify that once a patch is 'clean' it no longer increments the 'patches'.

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description: A dirt patch is specified thrice (3x) then passed over once. The expectation is that patches = 1 (if we're ignoring duplicate patches) or patches = 3 (if we're not).

item.description:
Requests in this folder verify accuracy of the number of dirt patches cleaned.

Some highlights include:
- Retracing over a patch once it's clean
- Does specifying the same patch twice make that patch twice as dirty?

item.description:
Requests in this folder attempt to send bad data and check how the API responds.

Bad data includes:
- String
- Decimal
- SQL

//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description:
How large can a room be? 

A width of 999,999,999 is allowed.
But a width of 9,999,999,999 is not.

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description:
How far can the Hoover travel?

This thing is like the energizer bunny!

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {
//If this next test fails, so will all others

request.description: How much dirt can one room hold?

item.description:
Requests in this folder attempt to answer some of the following exploratory questions:

- How large can a room be?
- Can I start outside of the room?
- How many dirt patches can we add?
- How many instructions will it accept?
